sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
From Wikipedia:

Following Doom's success, the source code for the Doom engine was released under GNU GPLv2 in 1997 by John Carmack (the original source code can be found at https://github.com/id-Software/DOOM). It now lives on in multiple ports, though you will still need to have a copy of the original game's data to play it and Doom 2 (also called the "IWAD").

sections.title: Games/WADs
sections.content: Also see List of games#Shooters (FPS, third person) for more Doom-related packages

sections.title: Freedoom
sections.content: Freedoom aims to be a completely free and open source reimagining of Doom. Install freedoomAUR.

sections.title: Doom Shareware
sections.content: The doom1-wadAUR package supplies the original Doom shareware IWAD.

sections.title: GZDoom
sections.content: An updated version of ZDoom, GZDoom is the go-to standard for compatibility with the most games based on the Doom engine. Install the gzdoomAUR package to install it.

sections.title: Chocolate Doom
sections.content: Chocolate Doom is a port that tries to be as historically-accurate to the original games as possible. Install chocolate-doomAUR.

sections.title: DOOM Retro
sections.content: DOOM Retro is based off of Chocolate Doom, but tailored to the project author's taste. Install doomretro.

sections.title: Editors
sections.content: There exist a number of editors to manipulate the data in Doom WADs in order to create maps, weapons, and even whole games using the Doom engine.

sections.title: SLADE
sections.content: SLADE is a WAD inspector, allowing users to see and modify the data lumps within, such as textures, sprites, scripts and info lumps. Install the sladeAUR package to install SLADE3.

sections.title: Ultimate Doom Builder
sections.content: Specifically a map editor, Ultimate Doom Builder is written in .NET, and is the de-facto standard for creating Doom maps. Install ultimate-doom-builder-gitAUR.

sections.title: Configuration
sections.content: Most Doom maps and mods will require a Doom or Doom 2 IWAD to work.

sections.title: GZDoom
sections.content:
The base GZDoom config file is located under ~/.config/gzdoom/gzdoom.ini.

To add the directory containing your IWADs so that GZDoom can see it, add the following to the config file underneath [IWADSearch.Directories]:

Path=<path>,

where <path> is the path to where your IWADs are.

sections.title: Troubleshooting
sections.content: A good resource for troubleshooting GZDoom is the ZDoom Wiki. It also has good resources on mapping, scripting, and other information when creating for Doom.
